org.jtrim.collections

Interface RefList.ElementRef<E>

  • Type Parameters:
    E - the type of the referenced element
    All Superinterfaces:
    RefCollection.ElementRef<E>
    Enclosing interface:
    RefList<E>

    public static interface RefList.ElementRef<E>
extends RefCollection.ElementRef<E>
    Defines a reference to an element of a RefList. The reference remains valid no matter how the underlying list was modified.

    Thread safety

    Instances of this class derive their thread-safety properties from the underlying collection.

      • Methods inherited from interface org.jtrim.collections.RefCollection.ElementRef

        getElement, isRemoved, remove, setElement

    • Method Detail

      • getIndex

        int getIndex()
        Returns the index of the element of this reference in the underlying list. Assume that list is the underlying list of ref, in this case the following condition must hold: ref.isRemoved() || ref == list.getReference(ref.getIndex()).

        Warning: This method must not be called after this reference was removed from the underlying list (i.e.: isRemoved() returns true).

        Returns:
        the index of the element of this reference in the underlying list. This method always returns an integer greater than or equal to zero.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - thrown if this reference was already removed from the underlying list

      • getIterator

        java.util.ListIterator<E> getIterator()
        Returns an iterator which will iterate through the elements of the underlying list starting from this element. The first element returned therefore will be this element.

        It is undefined how the returned iterator should work if the underlying list was modified while iterating through the returned iterator. Implementations may or may not fail to work under such condition. Therefore it is highly advised that the underlying list should not be modified while iterating through the elements of the return iterator.

        Warning: This method must not be called after this reference was removed from the underlying list (i.e.: isRemoved() returns true).

        Returns:
        an iterator which will iterate through the elements of the underlying list starting from this element. The first element returned therefore will be this element. This method never returns null.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - thrown if this reference was already removed from the underlying list

      • getNext

        RefList.ElementRef<E> getNext(int step)
        Returns the next stepth element of the underlying list. That is, this method returns the element with an index larger by step than the index of this element.

        This method is allowed to be called with a negative step argument, this is effectively calling getPrevious(Math.abs(step)) except when step == Integer.MIN_VALUE where it is the element one step before getPrevious(Integer.MAX_VALUE).

        Notice that getNext(0) always returns this reference.

        This method can be called after this referenced element was removed from the underlying list. In this case this method is defined to return null.

        Note to implementors: Don't forget that Math.abs(Integer.MIN_VALUE) == Integer.MIN_VALUE.

        Parameters:
        step - the number of elements to skip forward (including this reference). This argument can be any integer and negative values are effectively stepping backward with the absolute step value.
        Returns:
        the next element of the underlying list after skipping step number of elements (including this reference) or null if no such element exists (either because there is no such element in the underlying list or this element was already removed from the list)

      • getPrevious

        RefList.ElementRef<E> getPrevious(int step)
        Returns the previous stepth element of the underlying list. That is, this method returns the element with an index lower by step than the index of this element.

        This method is allowed to be called with a negative step argument, this is effectively calling getNext(Math.abs(step)) except when step == Integer.MIN_VALUE where it is the element one step after getNext(Integer.MAX_VALUE).

        Notice that getPrevious(0) always returns this reference.

        This method can be called after this referenced element was removed from the underlying list. In this case this method is defined to return null.

        Note to implementors: Don't forget that Math.abs(Integer.MIN_VALUE) == Integer.MIN_VALUE.

        Parameters:
        step - the number of elements to skip backward (including this reference). This argument can be any integer and negative values are effectively stepping forward with the absolute step value.
        Returns:
        the previous element of the underlying list after skipping step number of elements (including this reference) or null if no such element exists (either because there is no such element in the underlying list or this element was already removed from the list)

      • moveLast

        void moveLast()
        Makes the element referenced by this reference to be the last element of the underlying list. After this method returns successfully the index of this element will be the size of the underlying list minus one.

        Warning: This method must not be called after this reference was removed from the underlying list (i.e.: isRemoved() returns true).

        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - thrown if this reference was already removed from the underlying list

      • moveFirst

        void moveFirst()
        Makes the element referenced by this reference to be the last element of the underlying list. After this method returns successfully the index of this element will be zero.

        Warning: This method must not be called after this reference was removed from the underlying list (i.e.: isRemoved() returns true).

        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - thrown if this reference was already removed from the underlying list

      • moveBackward

        int moveBackward(int count)
        Moves the element referenced by this reference backward in the list by count if possible. This method will not move the reference out of the underlying list, instead this method will then make this reference as the first or last element of the underlying list (depending on the sign of count).

        This method is allowed to be called with negative argument. In this case this method call is effectively the same as calling moveForward(Math.abs(count)) except when count == Integer.MIN_VALUE where this method will move one step after moveForward(Integer.MAX_VALUE).

        Notice that calling moveBackward(0) does nothing.

        Warning: This method must not be called after this reference was removed from the underlying list (i.e.: isRemoved() returns true).

        Parameters:
        count - the amount to push this element backward in the underlying list. This argument can be any integer and negative values are effectively the same as moving forward with the absolute value.
        Returns:
        the amount this element was pushed backward in the underlying list. The new index of this reference was reduced by this amount. Note this value may not equal to the argument only if this element would needed to be pushed beyond the ends of the list.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - thrown if this reference was already removed from the underlying list

      • moveForward

        int moveForward(int count)
        Moves the element referenced by this reference forward in the list by count if possible. This method will not move the reference out of the underlying list, instead this method will then make this reference as the first or last element of the underlying list (depending on the sign of count).

        This method is allowed to be called with negative argument. In this case this method call is effectively the same as calling moveBackward(Math.abs(count)) except when count == Integer.MIN_VALUE where this method will move one step before moveBackward(Integer.MAX_VALUE).

        Notice that calling moveForward(0) does nothing.

        Warning: This method must not be called after this reference was removed from the underlying list (i.e.: isRemoved() returns true).

        Parameters:
        count - the amount to push this element forward in the underlying list. This argument can be any integer and negative values are effectively the same as moving backward with the absolute value.
        Returns:
        the amount this element was pushed forward in the underlying list. The new index of this reference was increased by this amount. Note this value may not equal to the argument only if this element would needed to be pushed beyond the ends of the list.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - thrown if this reference was already removed from the underlying list

      • addAfter

        RefList.ElementRef<E> addAfter(E newElement)
        Adds an element after the element referenced by this reference. The newly added element will be the next element in the underlying list after this reference.

        The following two asserts succeeds given a ref element reference and a newElement element:

        • ref.addAfter(newElement);

          assert ref.getNext(1).getElement() == newElement;

        • assert ref.addAfter(newElement).getIndex() == ref.getIndex() + 1;

        Warning: This method must not be called after this reference was removed from the underlying list (i.e.: isRemoved() returns true).

        Parameters:
        newElement - the new element to be added to the underlying list after this element. This argument can be null only if the underlying collection supports null elements.
        Returns:
        the element reference to the newly added element. This method never returns null.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - thrown if this reference was already removed from the underlying list
        java.lang.NullPointerException - thrown if this collection does not support null elements
        java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException - thrown if the underlying collection does not support new elements to added

      • addBefore

        RefList.ElementRef<E> addBefore(E newElement)
        Adds an element before the element referenced by this reference. The newly added element will be the previous element in the underlying list before this reference.

        The following two asserts succeeds given a ref element reference and a newElement element:

        • ref.addBefore(newElement);

          assert ref.getPrevious(1).getElement() == newElement;

        • assert ref.addBefore(newElement).getIndex() == ref.getIndex() - 1;

        Warning: This method must not be called after this reference was removed from the underlying list (i.e.: isRemoved() returns true).

        Parameters:
        newElement - the new element to be added to the underlying list before this element. This argument can be null only if the underlying collection supports null elements.
        Returns:
        the element reference to the newly added element. This method never returns null.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - thrown if this reference was already removed from the underlying list
        java.lang.NullPointerException - thrown if this collection does not support null elements
        java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException - thrown if the underlying collection does not support new elements to added
